sub_topic: Finding the perimeter of triangles using trigonometry
message_1: A right triangle has a hypotenuse of length 10 cm and one angle of 30 degrees. Find the length of the other two sides and the perimeter of the triangle.
message_2:
Let's call the side opposite the 30-degree angle "a" and the side adjacent to the 30-degree angle "b". We can use the sine and cosine functions to find the lengths of these sides.

sin(30) = a / 10
a = 10 * sin(30)
a = 10 * 0.5
a = 5 cm

cos(30) = b / 10
b = 10 * cos(30)
b = 10 * (√3 / 2)
b = 5√3 cm

Now that we have the lengths of the other two sides, we can find the perimeter of the triangle.

Perimeter = a + b + hypotenuse
Perimeter = 5 + 5√3 + 10
Perimeter = 15 + 5√3 cm
